title: Example `ldmppr` Workflow on Simulated Data
text: illustrate use ldmppr package, using included small_example_data dataset. dataset consists locations sizes points (25m x 25m) square domain. also include collection example raster files obtained ESS-DIVE repository (see help file small_example_data details).

title: Example `ldmppr` Workflow on Simulated Data
text: ldmppr package provides tools : estimating mechanistic spatio-temporal point process model reference marked point pattern (mapping marks event times), training mark model relates covariates (optional competition indices) marks, checking model fit using non-parametric summaries global envelope tests, simulating fitted model. version 1.1.0, main workflow functions return S3 objects standard methods (print(), plot(), coef(), .data.frame(), etc.). cases longer need helper plotting functions like plot_mpp().

what: Step 1: Estimate the point process parameters
title: Example `ldmppr` Workflow on Simulated Data
text: start estimating parameters self-correcting spatio-temporal point process using estimate_process_parameters function. function makes use user specified optimization algorithms nloptr function perform estimation log-likelihood optimization. function can run three different optimization strategies ("local", "global_local", "multires_global_local") allow user control approach. "local" strategy performs local optimization, "global_local" first runs global optimization uses solution starting point local optimization. Finally, "multires_global_local" strategy performs similarly "global_local", iterates local level increasing resolution spatio-temporal grid repeating local optimization increasing degrees polish. function requires observed locations observed arrival times, generated observed sizes using power law mapping function. inputs accepted : matrix/data.frame columns (time, x, y), matrix/data.frame columns (x, y, size) plus mapping hyperparameter delta (vector delta delta-search). power law mapping function depends hyperparameter delta, controls shape mapping relationship sizes arrival times. function also requires grid values optimization process, initial parameter values, upper bounds parameters, optimization algorithm (either global local, just local depending strategy) use. function returns optimal parameter estimates self-correcting point process. show common case start (x, y, size) delta = 1. Notes want search possible mappings size time, provide delta = c(...) set parallel = TRUE run one optimizer per delta (optionally parallel). better accuracy typically want denser grids vignette example; small grid chosen keep runtime modest.
code: # Use the (x, y, size) form and let estimate_process_parameters() construct time via delta parameter_estimation_data <- small_example_data  # Upper bounds for (t, x, y) ub <- c(1, 25, 25)  # Define the integration / grid schedule used by the likelihood approximation grids <- ldmppr_grids(   upper_bounds = ub,   levels = list(c(20, 20, 20)) )  # Define optimizer budgets/options for the global + local stages budgets <- ldmppr_budgets(   global_options = list(maxeval = 150),   local_budget_first_level = list(maxeval = 300, xtol_rel = 1e-5),   local_budget_refinement_levels = list(maxeval = 300, xtol_rel = 1e-5) )  # Parameter initialization values: (alpha1, beta1, gamma1, alpha2, beta2, alpha3, beta3, gamma3) parameter_inits <- c(1.5, 8.5, 0.015, 1.5, 3.2, 0.75, 3, 0.08)  fit_sc <- estimate_process_parameters(   data = parameter_estimation_data,   grids = grids,   budgets = budgets,   parameter_inits = parameter_inits,   delta = 1,   parallel = FALSE,   strategy = "global_local",   global_algorithm = "NLOPT_GN_CRS2_LM",   local_algorithm = "NLOPT_LN_BOBYQA",   verbose = TRUE ) #> Estimating self-correcting process parameters #>   Strategy: global_local #>   Delta: 1 #>   Grids: 1 level(s) #>   Local optimizer: NLOPT_LN_BOBYQA #>   Global optimizer: NLOPT_GN_CRS2_LM #>   Starts: global=1, local=1, jitter_sd=0.35, seed=1 #>   Parallel: off #> Step 1/2: Preparing data and objective function... #>   Prepared 121 points. #>   Done in 0.0s. #> Step 2/2: Optimizing parameters... #> Single level (grid 20x20x20) #>   Global search: 1 restart(s), then local refinement. #>   Completed in 0.5s. #>   Best objective: 174.58351 #> Finished. Total time: 0.5s. # Print method for ldmppr_fit objects fit_sc #> <ldmppr_fit> #>   process: self_correcting #>   engine:  nloptr #>   n_obs:   121 #>   delta*:  1 #>   objective (best): 174.5835 #>  optimal parameters:  -1.153893 10.13079 0.02562104 1.762711 2.576579 0.793192 2.500101 0.1115519  estimated_parameters <- coef(fit_sc) estimated_parameters #> [1] -1.15389260 10.13079399  0.02562104  1.76271138  2.57657919  0.79319202 #> [7]  2.50010138  0.11155188

title: Example `ldmppr` Workflow on Simulated Data
text: Next, use train_mark_model function train suitably flexible mark model using location-specific covariates (rasters), (optionally) semi-distance dependent competition indices, generated arrival times predict sizes. function uses either: gradient boosted trees (model_type = "xgboost"), random forest (model_type = "ranger"), may run parallel desired. user control choice Gradient Boosting Machine (GBM) Random Forest (RF) model, bounds spatial domain, inclusion competition indices, competition radius, correction method, final model selection metric, number cross validation folds, size parameter tuning grid model. user wants save trained mark model (reload later time), package provides save_mark_model load_mark_model functions (handle model-engine specifics appropriately):
code: # Load raster covariates shipped with the package raster_paths <- list.files(system.file("extdata", package = "ldmppr"),   pattern = "\\.tif$", full.names = TRUE ) raster_paths <- raster_paths[!grepl("_med\\.tif$", raster_paths)] rasters <- lapply(raster_paths, terra::rast)  # Scale rasters once up front scaled_rasters <- scale_rasters(rasters)  # Train the mark model, passing the estimated self-correcting model fit from Step 1 mark_model <- train_mark_model(   data = fit_sc,   raster_list = scaled_rasters,   scaled_rasters = TRUE,   model_type = "xgboost",   parallel = FALSE,   include_comp_inds = FALSE,   competition_radius = 10,   edge_correction = "none",   selection_metric = "rmse",   cv_folds = 5,   tuning_grid_size = 20,   verbose = TRUE ) #> Training mark model #>   Model type: xgboost #>   Selection metric: rmse #>   CV folds: 5 #>   Tuning grid size: 20 #>   Include competition indices: no #>   Edge correction: none #> Step 1/6: Preparing training data... #>   Rows: 121 #>   Done in 0.0s. #> Step 2/6: Configuring parallel backend... #>   Parallel: off #>   Model engine threads: 3 #>   Done in 0.0s. #> Step 3/6: Extracting raster covariates... #>   Using pre-scaled rasters (scaled_rasters = TRUE). #>   Extracted 4 raster feature(s). #>   Done in 0.0s. #> Step 4/6: Building model matrix (and competition indices if requested)... #>   Final training rows: 121 #>   Final feature columns (incl x,y,time): 7 #>   Done in 0.0s. #> Step 5/6: Fitting model (with optional CV tuning)... #>   Tuning enabled: 5-fold CV with 20 candidate(s). #>   Total model fits: 100 (5 folds x 20 grid). #>   Done in 28.9s. #> Step 6/6: Finalizing output object... #>   Done in 0.0s. #> Training complete. Total time: 28.9s.  # Print method for ldmppr_mark_model objects print(mark_model) #> <ldmppr_mark_model> #>   engine: xgboost #>   has fit_engine: TRUE #>   has xgb_raw: FALSE #>   n_features: 7  # Summary method for ldmppr_mark_model objects summary(mark_model) #>               Length Class       Mode        #> engine           1   -none-      character   #> fit_engine    1158   xgb.Booster list        #> xgb_raw          0   -none-      NULL        #> recipe          12   recipe      list        #> outcome          1   -none-      character   #> feature_names    7   -none-      character   #> info             7   -none-      list        #> cache            0   -none-      environment save_path <- tempfile(fileext = ".rds") save_mark_model(mark_model, save_path)  mark_model2 <- load_mark_model(save_path) mark_model2

title: Example `ldmppr` Workflow on Simulated Data
text: Now () estimated process model (ii) trained mark model, can check model fit using check_model_fit function. function provides variety non-parametric summaries point processes global envelope tests assess goodness fit model. package provides individual envelope tests L, F, G, J, E, V statistics, combined envelope test statistics simultaneously making use functionality spatstat GET packages. plotting combined envelope test, can visually assess goodness fit model obtain pp-value measuring well estimated model captures relationships observed reference data. Typically pp-value less 0.05 indicates poor fit model data, authors GET package recommend minimum 2500 simulations obtain valid pp-value .05 level. check_model_fit() returns S3 object plot() method (default plots combined global envelope test).  can still access underlying GET objects want (e.g., model_check$combined_env), workflows plot(model_check) sufficient.
code: # Check the model fit by passing the estimated process and trained mark models from Steps 1 and 2 model_check <- check_model_fit(   t_min = 0,   t_max = 1,   process = "self_correcting",   process_fit = fit_sc,   raster_list = scaled_rasters,   scaled_rasters = TRUE,   mark_model = mark_model,   include_comp_inds = FALSE,   thinning = TRUE,   edge_correction = "none",   competition_radius = 10,   n_sim = 100,   save_sims = FALSE,   verbose = TRUE,   seed = 90210 ) #> Registered S3 method overwritten by 'spatstat.geom': #>   method       from      #>   print.metric yardstick  # Plot method for ldmppr_model_check objects (defaults to combined global envelope test) plot(model_check)

what: Step 4: Simulate from the fitted model
title: Example `ldmppr` Workflow on Simulated Data
text: Finally, can simulate new marked point process realization fitted model. simulate_mpp() returns object class ldmppr_sim plot() .data.frame() methods.
code: # Simulate a new marked point pattern by passing the estimated process and trained mark models from Steps 1 and 2 simulated <- simulate_mpp(   process = "self_correcting",   process_fit = fit_sc,   t_min = 0,   t_max = 1,   raster_list = scaled_rasters,   scaled_rasters = TRUE,   mark_model = mark_model,   include_comp_inds = TRUE,   competition_radius = 10,   edge_correction = "none",   thinning = TRUE,   seed = 90210 )  # Plot method for ldmppr_sim plot(simulated) # Data-frame view of the simulated realization head(as.data.frame(simulated)) #>        time         x         y    marks #> 1 0.0000000 10.000000 14.000000 900.3945 #> 2 0.4430049 21.577247 23.111446 541.6990 #> 3 0.5039294 16.632781 22.061460 647.5046 #> 4 0.5408029  8.470302 22.657083 587.2133 #> 5 0.5605597 13.255630 11.320682 749.7777 #> 6 0.5762588 15.930922  8.571894 558.3950

title: Example `ldmppr` Workflow on Simulated Data
text: vignette demonstrates core ldmppr workflow using updated S3-based interfaces: estimate_process_parameters() → returns fitted process object (ldmppr_fit) train_mark_model() → returns fitted mark model object (ldmppr_mark_model) check_model_fit() → returns model-check object (ldmppr_model_check) simulate_mpp() → returns simulation object (ldmppr_sim) objects designed composable behave like standard R model objects S3 methods.

what: Check the fit of an estimated model using global envelope tests — check_model_fit
title: Check the fit of an estimated model using global envelope tests — check_model_fit
text: Performs global envelope tests nonparametric L, F, G, J, E, V summary functions (spatstat/GET). tests assess goodness--fit estimated model relative reference marked point pattern. reference marked point pattern can supplied directly via reference_data (marked ppp object), derived internally ldmppr_fit object.

title: Check the fit of an estimated model using global envelope tests — check_model_fit
code: check_model_fit(   reference_data = NULL,   t_min = 0,   t_max = 1,   process = c("self_correcting"),   process_fit = NULL,   anchor_point = NULL,   raster_list = NULL,   scaled_rasters = FALSE,   mark_model = NULL,   xy_bounds = NULL,   include_comp_inds = FALSE,   thinning = TRUE,   edge_correction = "none",   competition_radius = 15,   n_sim = 2500,   save_sims = TRUE,   verbose = TRUE,   seed = 0,   parallel = FALSE,   num_cores = max(1L, parallel::detectCores() - 1L),   set_future_plan = FALSE,   mark_delta = NULL )

title: Check the fit of an estimated model using global envelope tests — check_model_fit
text: reference_data (optional) marked ppp object reference dataset. NULL, reference pattern derived process_fit process_fit ldmppr_fit contains data_original (preferred) data columns (x,y,size). t_min minimum value time. t_max maximum value time. process type process used (currently supports "self_correcting"). process_fit either ldmppr_fit object (estimate_process_parameters) numeric vector length 8 giving process parameters. anchor_point (optional) vector (x,y) coordinates point condition . NULL, inferred reference data (largest mark available) ldmppr_fit. raster_list list raster objects used predicting marks. scaled_rasters TRUE FALSE indicating whether rasters already scaled. mark_model mark model object. May ldmppr_mark_model legacy model. xy_bounds (optional) vector bounds c(a_x, b_x, a_y, b_y). NULL, inferred reference_data's window reference_data provided, otherwise ldmppr_fit lower bounds assumed 0. include_comp_inds TRUE FALSE indicating whether compute competition indices. thinning TRUE FALSE indicating whether use thinned simulated values. edge_correction type edge correction apply ("none" "toroidal"). competition_radius distance competition radius include_comp_inds = TRUE. n_sim number simulated datasets generate. save_sims TRUE FALSE indicating whether save return simulated metrics. verbose TRUE FALSE indicating whether show progress model checking. TRUE, progress reported via progressr (available) compatible parallel execution. seed integer seed reproducibility. parallel TRUE FALSE. TRUE, simulations run parallel via furrr/future. num_cores number workers use parallel=TRUE. Defaults one fewer number detected cores. set_future_plan TRUE FALSE. TRUE parallel=TRUE, set local future plan internally (default behavior uses multisession). mark_delta (optional) numeric value rescale time covariate used mark model.

title: Check the fit of an estimated model using global envelope tests — check_model_fit
text: function relies spatstat package calculation point pattern metrics GET package global envelope tests. L, F, G, J, E, V functions collection non-parametric summary statistics describe spatial distribution points marks point pattern. See documentation Lest(), Fest(), Gest(), Jest(), Emark(), Vmark() information. Also, see global_envelope_test() function information global envelope tests.

title: Check the fit of an estimated model using global envelope tests — check_model_fit
text: Baddeley, ., Rubak, E., & Turner, R. (2015). *Spatial Point Patterns: Methodology Applications R*. Chapman Hall/CRC Press, London. ISBN 9781482210200. Available : https://www.routledge.com/Spatial-Point-Patterns-Methodology--Applications--R/Baddeley-Rubak-Turner/p/book/9781482210200. Myllymäki, M., & Mrkvička, T. (2023). GET: Global envelopes R. arXiv:1911.06583 [stat.]. doi:10.48550/arXiv.1911.06583 .

title: Check the fit of an estimated model using global envelope tests — check_model_fit
code: # Note: The example below is provided for illustrative purposes and may take some time to run. # \donttest{ data(small_example_data)  file_path <- system.file("extdata", "example_mark_model.rds", package = "ldmppr") mark_model <- load_mark_model(file_path)  raster_paths <- list.files(system.file("extdata", package = "ldmppr"),                            pattern = "\\.tif$", full.names = TRUE) raster_paths <- raster_paths[!grepl("_med\\.tif$", raster_paths)] rasters <- lapply(raster_paths, terra::rast) scaled_raster_list <- scale_rasters(rasters)  reference_data <- generate_mpp(   locations = small_example_data[, c("x", "y")],   marks = small_example_data$size,   xy_bounds = c(0, 25, 0, 25) ) #> Registered S3 method overwritten by 'spatstat.geom': #>   method       from      #>   print.metric yardstick  estimated_parameters <- c(   0.05167978, 8.20702166, 0.02199940, 2.63236890,   1.82729512, 0.65330061, 0.86666748, 0.04681878 )  # NOTE: examples are run by CRAN with --run-donttest; keep parallel=FALSE here. example_model_fit <- check_model_fit(   reference_data = reference_data,   t_min = 0,   t_max = 1,   process = "self_correcting",   process_fit = estimated_parameters,   raster_list = scaled_raster_list,   scaled_rasters = TRUE,   mark_model = mark_model,   xy_bounds = c(0, 25, 0, 25),   include_comp_inds = TRUE,   thinning = TRUE,   edge_correction = "none",   competition_radius = 10,   n_sim = 100,   save_sims = FALSE,   verbose = TRUE,   seed = 90210,   parallel = FALSE )  plot(example_model_fit, which = 'combined') #> Warning: `aes_string()` was deprecated in ggplot2 3.0.0. #> ℹ Please use tidy evaluation idioms with `aes()`. #> ℹ See also `vignette("ggplot2-in-packages")` for more information. #> ℹ The deprecated feature was likely used in the GET package. #>   Please report the issue at <https://github.com/myllym/GET/issues>. #> Warning: `aes_()` was deprecated in ggplot2 3.0.0. #> ℹ Please use tidy evaluation idioms with `aes()` #> ℹ The deprecated feature was likely used in the GET package. #>   Please report the issue at <https://github.com/myllym/GET/issues>.  # }

code: estimate_process_parameters(   data,   process = c("self_correcting"),   grids,   budgets,   parameter_inits = NULL,   delta = NULL,   parallel = FALSE,   num_cores = max(1L, parallel::detectCores() - 1L),   set_future_plan = FALSE,   strategy = c("local", "global_local", "multires_global_local"),   global_algorithm = "NLOPT_GN_CRS2_LM",   local_algorithm = "NLOPT_LN_BOBYQA",   starts = list(global = 1L, local = 1L, jitter_sd = 0.35, seed = 1L),   finite_bounds = NULL,   refine_best_delta = TRUE,   verbose = TRUE )

title: Estimate point process parameters using log-likelihood maximization — estimate_process_parameters
text: data data.frame matrix. Must contain either columns (time, x, y) (x, y, size). matrix provided without time, must column names c("x","y","size"). process type process used (currently supports "self_correcting"). grids ldmppr_grids object specifying integration grid schedule (single-level multi-resolution). integration bounds taken grids$upper_bounds. budgets ldmppr_budgets object controlling optimizer options global stage local stages (first level vs refinement levels). parameter_inits (optional) numeric vector length 8 giving initialization values model parameters. NULL, defaults derived data grids$upper_bounds. delta (optional) numeric scalar vector. Used data contain time (.e., data (x,y,size)). length(delta) == 1, fits model using power_law_mapping(size, delta). length(delta) > 1, performs delta-search fitting model candidate value     selecting best objective. refine_best_delta = TRUE multiple grid levels used,     best delta refined remaining (finer) grid levels. data already contains time, delta ignored length(delta)==1 error length(delta)>1. parallel TRUE FALSE specifying furrr/future parallelize either: () candidate delta values (length(delta) > 1), /(b) local multi-start initializations (starts$local > 1), /(c) global restarts (starts$global > 1). num_cores number workers use set_future_plan = TRUE. set_future_plan TRUE FALSE, temporarily sets future::plan(multisession, workers = num_cores) restores original plan exit. strategy character string specifying estimation strategy: "local": local optimization (single-level multi-level polish). "global_local": global optimization local polish (single grid level). "multires_global_local": multi-resolution (coarsest uses global+local; refinements use local ). global_algorithm, local_algorithm NLopt algorithms use global local optimization stages, respectively. starts list controlling restart jitter behavior: global: integer, number global restarts first/coarsest level (default 1). local: integer, number local multi-starts per level (default 1). jitter_sd: numeric SD jittering (default 0.35). seed: integer base seed (default 1). finite_bounds (optional) list components lb ub giving finite lower upper bounds 8 parameters. NULL, bounds derived parameter_inits. Global algorithms select local algorithms NLopt require finite bounds. refine_best_delta TRUE FALSE. TRUE length(delta) > 1, performs refinement best delta across additional grid levels (available). verbose TRUE FALSE indicating whether show progress model estimation.

title: Estimate point process parameters using log-likelihood maximization — estimate_process_parameters
text: object class "ldmppr_fit" containing best nloptr fit   (optionally) stored fits global restarts /delta search.

title: Estimate point process parameters using log-likelihood maximization — estimate_process_parameters
text: self-correcting process, arrival times must lie \((0,1)\) can supplied directly data time, constructed size via gentle-decay (power-law) mapping power_law_mapping using delta. delta vector, model fit candidate value best objective selected. function supports multi-resolution estimation via ldmppr_grids schedule. multiple grid levels provided, coarsest level may use global optimizer followed local refinement, subsequent levels run local refinement .

title: Estimate point process parameters using log-likelihood maximization — estimate_process_parameters
text: Møller, J., Ghorbani, M., & Rubak, E. (2016). Mechanistic spatio-temporal point process models marked point processes, view forest stand data. Biometrics, 72(3), 687-696. doi:10.1111/biom.12466 .

title: Estimate point process parameters using log-likelihood maximization — estimate_process_parameters
code: # Load example data data(small_example_data)  # Define grids and budgets ub <- c(1, 25, 25) g  <- ldmppr_grids(upper_bounds = ub, levels = list(c(10,10,10))) b  <- ldmppr_budgets(   global_options = list(maxeval = 150),   local_budget_first_level = list(maxeval = 50, xtol_rel = 1e-2),   local_budget_refinement_levels = list(maxeval = 25, xtol_rel = 1e-2) )  # Estimate parameters using a single delta value fit <- estimate_process_parameters(   data = small_example_data,   grids = g,   budgets = b,   delta = 1,   strategy = "global_local",   global_algorithm = "NLOPT_GN_CRS2_LM",   local_algorithm  = "NLOPT_LN_BOBYQA",   starts = list(global = 2, local = 2, jitter_sd = 0.25, seed = 1),   verbose = TRUE ) #> Using default starting values (parameter_inits) since none were provided. #>   Initial values: 7.185, 0.01, 0.03963, 2.369, 2, 0.5, 2.369, 0.05 #> Estimating self-correcting process parameters #>   Strategy: global_local #>   Delta: 1 #>   Grids: 1 level(s) #>   Local optimizer: NLOPT_LN_BOBYQA #>   Global optimizer: NLOPT_GN_CRS2_LM #>   Starts: global=2, local=2, jitter_sd=0.25, seed=1 #>   Parallel: off #> Step 1/2: Preparing data and objective function... #>   Prepared 121 points. #>   Done in 0.0s. #> Step 2/2: Optimizing parameters... #> Single level (grid 10x10x10) #>   Global search: 2 restart(s), then local refinement. #>   Local multi-start: 2 start(s). #>   Completed in 0.1s. #>   Best objective: 317.13058 #> Finished. Total time: 0.1s. coef(fit) #> [1] 4.757216e+00 2.190015e-02 8.182097e-07 1.493670e-06 2.722307e+00 #> [6] 8.140992e-07 4.958124e+00 8.890184e-02 logLik(fit) #> 'log Lik.' -317.1306 (df=8)  # \donttest{ # Estimate parameters using multiple delta values (delta search) g2 <- ldmppr_grids(upper_bounds = ub, levels = list(c(8,8,8), c(12,12,12))) fit_delta <- estimate_process_parameters(   data = small_example_data, # x,y,size   grids = g2,   budgets = b,   delta = c(0.35, 0.5, 0.65, 0.9, 1.0),   parallel = TRUE,   set_future_plan = TRUE,   num_cores = 2,   strategy = "multires_global_local",   starts = list(local = 1),   refine_best_delta = FALSE,   verbose = FALSE ) plot(fit_delta)  # }

text: suite tools estimating, assessing model fit, simulating , visualizing location dependent marked point processes characterized regularity pattern. provide reference marked point process, set raster images containing location specific covariates, select estimation algorithm type mark model. title: Simulate a realization of a location dependent marked point process — simulate_mpp
text: process type process used (currently supports "self_correcting"). process_fit either (1) ldmppr_fit object returned estimate_process_parameters, (2) numeric vector length 8 giving self-correcting parameters: \((\alpha_1,\beta_1,\gamma_1,\alpha_2,\beta_2,\alpha_3,\beta_3,\gamma_3)\) (alpha_1, beta_1, gamma_1, alpha_2, beta_2, alpha_3, beta_3, gamma_3). t_min minimum value time. t_max maximum value time. anchor_point (optional) vector (x,y) coordinates point condition . NULL, inferred reference data (largest mark available) process_fit$data_original (largest size). raster_list list raster objects used predicting marks. scaled_rasters TRUE FALSE indicating whether rasters already scaled. mark_model mark model object. May ldmppr_mark_model legacy model. xy_bounds (optional) vector bounds c(a_x, b_x, a_y, b_y). NULL, inferred reference_data's window reference_data provided, otherwise ldmppr_fit lower bounds assumed 0. include_comp_inds TRUE FALSE indicating whether compute competition indices. competition_radius distance competition radius include_comp_inds = TRUE. edge_correction type edge correction apply ("none" "toroidal"). thinning TRUE FALSE indicating whether use thinned simulated values. seed integer seed reproducibility.

title: Simulate a realization of a location dependent marked point process — simulate_mpp
text: object class "ldmppr_sim".

title: Simulate a realization of a location dependent marked point process — simulate_mpp
code: # Specify the generating parameters of the self-correcting process generating_parameters <- c(2, 8, .02, 2.5, 3, 1, 2.5, .2)  # Specify an anchor point M_n <- c(10, 14)  # Load the raster files raster_paths <- list.files(system.file("extdata", package = "ldmppr"),   pattern = "\\.tif$", full.names = TRUE ) raster_paths <- raster_paths[!grepl("_med\\.tif$", raster_paths)] rasters <- lapply(raster_paths, terra::rast)  # Scale the rasters scaled_raster_list <- scale_rasters(rasters)  # Load the example mark model file_path <- system.file("extdata", "example_mark_model.rds", package = "ldmppr") mark_model <- load_mark_model(file_path)  # Simulate a realization example_mpp <- simulate_mpp(   process = "self_correcting",   process_fit = generating_parameters,   t_min = 0,   t_max = 1,   anchor_point = M_n,   raster_list = scaled_raster_list,   scaled_rasters = TRUE,   mark_model = mark_model,   xy_bounds = c(0, 25, 0, 25),   include_comp_inds = TRUE,   competition_radius = 10,   edge_correction = "none",   thinning = TRUE )  # Plot the realization and provide a summary plot(example_mpp, pattern_type = "simulated")  summary(example_mpp) #>                    Length Class      Mode      #> process             1     -none-     character #> mpp                 6     ppp        list      #> realization         4     data.frame list      #> params              8     -none-     numeric   #> bounds              3     -none-     list      #> anchor_point        2     -none-     numeric   #> thinning            1     -none-     logical   #> edge_correction     1     -none-     character #> include_comp_inds   1     -none-     logical   #> competition_radius  1     -none-     numeric   #> call               14     -none-     call      #> meta                2     -none-     list

title: Train a flexible model for the mark distribution — train_mark_model
text: data data.frame ldmppr_fit object. See Description. raster_list list raster objects. scaled_rasters TRUE FALSE indicating whether rasters scaled. model_type machine learning model type ("xgboost" "random_forest"). xy_bounds vector domain bounds (2 x, 2 y). data ldmppr_fit xy_bounds NULL, defaults c(0, b_x, 0, b_y) derived fit. delta (optional) numeric scalar used data contains (x,y,size) time. data ldmppr_fit time missing, function infer delta value fit. save_model TRUE FALSE indicating whether save generated model. save_path path saving generated model. parallel TRUE FALSE indicating whether use parallelization model training. num_cores number cores use parallel model training (parallel TRUE). include_comp_inds TRUE FALSE indicating whether generate use competition indices covariates. competition_radius distance competition radius include_comp_inds TRUE. edge_correction type edge correction apply ("none", "toroidal", "truncation"). selection_metric metric use identifying optimal model ("rmse", "mae", "rsq"). cv_folds number cross-validation folds use model training. cv_folds <= 1, tuning skipped model fit default hyperparameters. tuning_grid_size size tuning grid hyperparameter tuning. verbose TRUE FALSE indicating whether show progress model training.

title: Train a flexible model for the mark distribution — train_mark_model
text: object class "ldmppr_mark_model" containing trained mark model.

title: Train a flexible model for the mark distribution — train_mark_model
code: # Load the small example data data(small_example_data)  # Load example raster data raster_paths <- list.files(system.file("extdata", package = "ldmppr"),   pattern = "\\.tif$", full.names = TRUE ) raster_paths <- raster_paths[!grepl("_med\\.tif$", raster_paths)] rasters <- lapply(raster_paths, terra::rast)  # Scale the rasters scaled_raster_list <- scale_rasters(rasters)   # Train the model mark_model <- train_mark_model(   data = small_example_data,   raster_list = scaled_raster_list,   scaled_rasters = TRUE,   model_type = "xgboost",   xy_bounds = c(0, 25, 0, 25),   delta = 1,   parallel = FALSE,   include_comp_inds = FALSE,   competition_radius = 10,   edge_correction = "none",   selection_metric = "rmse",   cv_folds = 3,   tuning_grid_size = 2,   verbose = TRUE ) #> Training mark model #>   Model type: xgboost #>   Selection metric: rmse #>   CV folds: 3 #>   Tuning grid size: 2 #>   Include competition indices: no #>   Edge correction: none #> Step 1/6: Preparing training data... #>   Rows: 121 #>   Done in 0.0s. #> Step 2/6: Configuring parallel backend... #>   Parallel: off #>   Model engine threads: 3 #>   Done in 0.0s. #> Step 3/6: Extracting raster covariates... #>   Using pre-scaled rasters (scaled_rasters = TRUE). #>   Extracted 4 raster feature(s). #>   Done in 0.0s. #> Step 4/6: Building model matrix (and competition indices if requested)... #>   Final training rows: 121 #>   Final feature columns (incl x,y,time): 7 #>   Done in 0.0s. #> Step 5/6: Fitting model (with optional CV tuning)... #>   Tuning enabled: 3-fold CV with 2 candidate(s). #>   Total model fits: 6 (3 folds x 2 grid). #>   Done in 2.7s. #> Step 6/6: Finalizing output object... #>   Done in 0.0s. #> Training complete. Total time: 2.7s.  print(mark_model) #> <ldmppr_mark_model> #>   engine: xgboost #>   has fit_engine: TRUE #>   has xgb_raw: FALSE #>   n_features: 7

title: ldmppr 1.1.1
text: CRAN release: 2026-01-13 Updated workflow pipeline allow passage S3 class objects functions simplify user experience. four main steps workflow (fit process model, train mark model, check model fit, simulate realizations) now S3 class associated methods can pass objects forward functions. See updated documentation details.

title: ldmppr 1.1.0
text: CRAN release: 2026-01-08 Introduced S3 classes associated methods 4 main workflow steps (fit process model/train mark model/check model fit/simulate realizations). Replaced estimate_parameters_sc() estimate_parameters_sc_parallel() functions unified estimate_process_parameters() function. redesigned function provide multiple strategies optimization procedure refactored underlying C++ code improve efficiency. Removed explicit dependence Bundle package introduced save_mark_model() load_mark_model() functions handle saving loading trained mark models.
